thread.title: Former Fox News Host Gretchen Carlson Returns To TV For The First Time Since Suing Roger Ailes
thread.title_full: Former Fox News Host Gretchen Carlson Returns To TV For The First Time Since Suing Roger Ailes

author: Alicia Powe
title: Former Fox News Host Gretchen Carlson Returns To TV For The First Time Since Suing Roger Ailes
text:
Former Fox News Host Gretchen Carlson Returns To TV For The First Time Since Suing Roger Ailes "One of the things I want to do is ..." by Alicia Powe January 3, 2017 at 1:54pm Share on Facebook Share Tweet Email Email Print Advertisement - story continues below 
Former Fox News anchor Gretchen Carlson co-hosted the Today show on Tuesday, marking her first live television appearance since filing a sexual harassment lawsuit against former Fox News chairman Roger Ailes last July. 
Joining NBC’s Al Roker and Sheinelle Jones, Carlson says she is looking forward to 2017. 
“New beginnings. I’m a huge believer in being optimistic and starting over and getting a fresh start,” she explained. Advertisement - story continues below 
Carlson announced during the segment that she will be working as a columnist for Motto, a women focused site launched last year by Fortune parent company Time Inc. 
“One of the things I want to do is to give back,” she said, “and I’m setting up a fund to empower women and young girls that I will be contributing to.” 
Her first article for the website will be published on Jan. 16. Advertisement - story continues below 
The former Miss USA also recounted highlights of her career on the segment, including her longtime passion for playing the violin and her performance during the 1989 Miss America pageant. 
The Today show is reportedly having difficulty finding a long-term replacement after Billy Bush left the program following controversy from filmed footage during a former Access Hollywood session with Donald Trump. 
The time slot will eventually need to be filled with a permanent host, but according to Variety , Carlson is expected to only be a temporary guest host. Advertisement - story continues below
